card.desc:
[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages "smartCard-inline")

If no cover was provided, you should fabricate one for the ebook. See [here](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Easy_Epub/Cover "‌") for more information.

And [here](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages/Blank_Book_Covers "‌") are blank cover images to start from.

You will need a public domain declaration. This is a PG requirement. This should go into the Transcriber’s Notes at the end of the book.

> New original cover art included with this eBook is granted to the public domain.

In ppgen, wrap this disclaimer with an HTML test. There is no cover in the text file, therefore no reason for the disclaimer.

```
.if h
.de .covernote { visibility: hidden; display: none; }
.de .x-ebookmaker .covernote { visibility: visible; display: block; }
.dv class="covernote"
New original cover art included with this eBook is granted to the public domain.
.dv-
.if-
```

The HTML version doesn't really need a cover, so if we are at the point of fabricating one, then we only want it to be applied to the ebook. The above ppgen code will result in an HTML file that won't display the cover. The ebook will still include the cover.

DP policy is that when fabricating a cover image, we use only images found within the book as provided (not images found in other versions of the book, or images from anywhere else). See more at the above link.

There is a [team thread](http://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=57674 "‌") of people who are willing to volunteer to create custom covers for projects.

## Pixelmator Pro how-to

First grab a [generic cover image](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages/Blank_Book_Covers "‌"), at least 1600x2560 pixels.

Select a font. All-caps and something akin to the title page font might be a good selection. Serif fonts are probably best. Here are some possibilities:

- Academy Engraved LET
- Palatino
- Times New Roman

Use as large a font size as will fit: 96 point generally works, or 72 if necessary; and perhaps much smaller for "By" above an Author's name. Center it. Try to use a color complementary to the cover's color.

Add the title and author text on separate layers. That way they can be moved around.

card.desc:
Always use Preview first. It will let you know if you have any extra files in your zip file, if the HTML does not validate, or if there is some other problem with your file.

If all is well, in preview mode you will see something like the following:

> user's upload was UTF-8testing turkeyinthestraw.html HTML Tidy: No warnings or errors were found. W3C HTML check passed CSS passed (level 3) Valid links and anchors

If there is a problem, you may see a message warning of invalid HTML, CSS or bad links, etc.

Details of the problems will be provided via a link to a temporary location on PG's server. If the preview indicates any problems with the HTML, please revise to address these problems, and upload the file for preview again.

**Only submit if the preview no longer indicates any problems.**

card.desc: Add the transcriber's notes that you've been keeping. I use the original book's page numbers; it's better than using the image numbers, even though in the output text version there are no page numbers. Include a bit of text for change entries, so the reader can find the place you changed. `p. 123: changed "foo" to "fool" (the fool and his money)` A boilerplate to start from: ``` .pb .de .tnotes { width: 80%; margin: auto; padding: 0 1em; background-color: #E3E4FA; border: 1px solid silver; } .dv class="tnotes" .ce Transcriber’s Notes: Some inconsistencies in spelling, hyphenation, and punctuation have been retained. .if t This file uses underscores to indicate italic text. .if- .dv- ```

I use the original book's page numbers for some reason, it's better than using the image numbers I guess, even though in the text version there are no page numbers. **Leading TN, if any, should be right after** `.dt` **before the Page 1 mark** Include a bit of text for change entries, so the reader can find the place you changed. `p. 123: changed "foo" to "fool" (the fool and his money)` An easy boilerplate to start from: ``` .h2 Transcriber’s Notes Some inconsistencies in spelling, hyphenation, and punctuation have been retained. .if t This file uses underscores to indicate italic text. .if- ```

card.desc:
Illustrations are in `illustrations/` to clean up `pngs/`, but save the final output images to `images` folder.

(In June 2020, the guidelines were updated by PG, see [this thread](https://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=70286 "‌")).

Covers. Covers should be at least 650x1000 pixels (width x height) and up to 5000x5000 pixels. Larger dimensions are recommended. Cover file size should be no larger than 256K.

Inline images. Normal illustrations should be no larger than 256K and up to 5000x5000 pixels in dimension.

Linked-to images. Images that are targets of an href can be no larger than 1 MB and up to 5000x5000 pixels.

They should be sized proportional to how much space they took on the printed page. e.g. an illustrated drop cap is probably only 100-125px tall. Using the image guidelines as a guide, you can also control the rendering size using CSS width. But an image should only be as large as needed, we still don't want to balloon download sizes unnecessarily.

Monochrome images, use PNG. Color images use JPEG.

JPEG can't do transparency, if you need transparency, add an alpha channel to the source image and export as PNG.

JPEG is much more compressible, so a large PNG can probably benefit from being converted to JPEG.

Images with captions don't need an `alt` tag.

[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Guide_to_Image_Processing](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Guide_to_Image_Processing "smartCard-inline")

[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/DP_Official_Documentation:PP_and_PPV/Post-Processing_FAQ#Preparing_illustrations_for_the_HTML_version](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/DP_Official_Documentation:PP_and_PPV/Post-Processing_FAQ#Preparing_illustrations_for_the_HTML_version "smartCard-inline")

If fixing the image is beyond your ability, try asking for help in the [Illustrators thread](http://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=17712 "‌").

card.desc: [https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages "smartCard-inline") If no cover was provided, you should fabricate one for the ebook. See [here](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Easy_Epub/Cover "‌") for more information. And [here](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages/Blank_Book_Covers "‌") are blank cover images to start from. You will need a front matter TN, and a public domain declaration. This is a PG requirement. Something like "The cover image was created by the transcriber and is placed in the public domain." See below for code. In ppgen, wrap this disclaimer with an HTML test. There is no cover in the text file, therefore no reason for the disclaimer. ``` .if h .de div.tnotes { padding-left:1em;padding-right:1em;background-color:#E3E4FA;border:1px solid silver; margin:2em 10% 0 10%; } .de .covernote { visibility: hidden; display: none; } .de div.tnotes p { text-align:left; } .de @media handheld { .covernote { visibility: visible; display: block;} } .dv class="tnotes covernote" Transcriber's Note: New original cover art included with this eBook is granted to the public domain. .dv- .if- ``` The HTML version doesn't really need a cover, so if we are at the point of fabricating one, then we only want it to be applied to the ebook. The above ppgen code will result in an HTML file that won't display the cover. The ebook will still include the cover. DP policy is that when fabricating a cover image, we use only images found within the book as provided (not images found in other versions of the book, or images from anywhere else). See more at the above link. There is a [team thread](http://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=57674 "‌") of people who are willing to volunteer to create custom covers for projects. ## Pixelmator Pro how-to First grab a [generic cover image](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages/Blank_Book_Covers "‌"), at least 1600x2560 pixels. Select a font. All-caps and something akin to the title page font might be a good selection. Serif fonts are probably best. Here are some possibilities: - Academy Engraved LET - Palatino - Times New Roman Use as large a font size as will fit: 96 point generally works, or 72 if necessary; and perhaps much smaller for "By" above an Author's name. Center it. Try to use a color complementary to the cover's color. Add the title and author text on separate layers. That way they can be moved around.

card.desc:
If this book uses drop caps, add those.

Use `.dc` for text (`.di` is for drop cap images).

If a book has the drop cap text printed all in one case, but it contains a capital letter such as a name, _preserve the capital_ even though it will look different. Some epub formatters, including ADE, cannot do small caps, so then you will end up with an improper case.

**For illustrated drop caps, leave this for when images are processed.**

[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Manual#Drop\_Caps\_.28Letters.29](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Manual#Drop_Caps_.28Letters.29 "‌")

card.desc:
Set up source file so it is aware of the book's page numbering. This makes it easy to locate things later.

```
Search: ^-+File: (\d+\.png)-+\s*$
Replace: .bn $1\n.pn +1
```

‌

- ppgen has facilities for page numbering but, also png numbering
- Insert a comment to replace a page marker
- Set the page number with e.g. `.pn 1`
- Advance page number by 1 with `.pn +1`
- Set a .bin file up for this page with e.g. `.bn 001.png`

See also [Page Numbering](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Manual#Page_Numbering "‌").

card.desc:
Replace `--` with UTF-8 em-dash.

```
[^-]--[^-]
```

When ppgen generates its output files, it will use "—" for the em-dashes in the utf8.txt file and the .html file. For the lat1.txt file ppgen will convert the em-dashes back to "--".

Single dashes are in 2 categories:

- A hyphen, which should be left as-is
- An en-dash, which can be inserted as the UTF-8 character.

An en-dash is appropriate in these cases:

- Range of numbers `12–15`
- A mathematical minus sign `15 – 12 = 3`
- Negative numbers `–14º`

[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/En-dash](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/En-dash "‌")

cards.desc:
[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Guiguts_PP_Process_Checklist#Apply_Word-Frequency_Checks_(10-60_min.)](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Guiguts_PP_Process_Checklist#Apply_Word-Frequency_Checks_(10-60_min.) "smartCard-inline")

[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/DP_Official_Documentation:PP_and_PPV/Post-Processing_FAQ#Keep_a_%22To_Do%22_list](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/DP_Official_Documentation:PP_and_PPV/Post-Processing_FAQ#Keep_a_%22To_Do%22_list "smartCard-inline")
cards.name: PP FAQ

cards.desc:
Should be simple, no spaces, lowercase, e.g. "missfairfax" was used for "Miss Fairfax of Virginia".

This is used by scripts and to name the GitHub repo, so use it consistently.
cards.name: Choosing a project name

cards.desc:
Set up the project directory, populate with the project files. This script will also create a Trello board and Github repository.

```
cd ~/dp/util
. venv/bin/activate
./make_project.py
```
cards.name: Set up project

cards.desc: Make sure you have notes on prior discussion so it's not forgotten.
cards.name: Read forum & project directions

cards.desc:
If Guiguts is set up for it,

Custom → Open page images in Preview

Which runs:

`open -a Preview -g $path_to_pngs/*.png`

We specifically open with the wildcard because otherwise they will not be sorted in the sidebar.

Specifying .png will avoid opening any .jpg that are bundled.
cards.name: Image viewing

cards.desc:
If any vertical space is needed, use `.sp`:

```
.sp   Space one line vertically.
.sp N Space N lines vertically.
```
cards.name: Adding vertical space

cards.desc:
https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP/Hanging_Indent

https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Guiguts/Guiguts_Manual/Text_Menu#Table_with_Long_Text_Passages
cards.name: Hanging indents

cards.desc: Not going to write this all up for now, but I did one of these in Winefred, can look there for some ideas.
cards.name: Advertisements

cards.desc:
From PP mentor:

> Standard indexes (with just a few levels of indentation) are quite easy to handle, even in the HTML version; provided that the formatters did their job thoroughly for the text version. Just go back to the the text version, copy the index, and paste it into an empty Guiguts window (you can either close the text file or even open another instance of Guiguts). Now, just highlight the pasted list and run 'HTML Auto Index (List)' from the 'HTML' menu. Guiguts will produce the HTML code within a few seconds, which you can subsequently paste into your HTML version. You just have to check for incorrect links (e.g., numbers which are not page numbers), and you are done. Of course, you can always adjust the appearance of your index by applying a few additional CSS classes. But please, be very careful and don't forget to keep a backup for your original HTML file--just in case

http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/User:Miller#Index
cards.name: Index (TBD)

cards.desc: PPgen 3.57e or later should output HTML5.
cards.name: HTML5

cards.desc:
A regex to find Latin-1 accented and special characters.

```
[\xa0-\xff]
```

Note that this will also match on UTF-8 encoded Latin characters, so this is not a way to locate ISO-8859-1 encodings, only a way to locate accented characters.
cards.name: Finding accented characters

cards.desc:
Find the best resolution of the scan you can get (TIA, etc).

Carefully look at the shape of the letters.

Ref: [Æ and œ ligatures](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/%C3%86_and_%C5%93_ligatures)
cards.name: ae/oe ligatures

cards.desc:
**DO THIS AFTER GUTCHECK / BOOKLOUPE!**

[Miller's workflow](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/User:Miller#Greek "‌")

Post in the [forum](https://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=15744 "‌") asking for help. Include the text to transcribe (as it appears in the proofer output) and links to the PNGs and/or high-quality scans.

Then when someone responds, simply copy/paste their output into the text file. Then remove the `[Greek: ...]` tag entirely, the new text replaces it.

Use `<i>` tags if the text is italic, as normal.

This only works for UTF-8 so if for some reason you aren't doing a UTF-8 version, then skip this and leave the transliterated latin text instead.
cards.name: Greek

cards.desc:
Don't even try to do this by yourself, post in the forum, there's a great guy that will just do the Hebrew for you.

If you have Hebrew in the project, make sure to tell PPV (and have them mention to WW) so they know to expect it.

**NOTE** Hebrew will break gutcheck (bookloupe) - may be better to wait until after gutcheck time to insert it, though that will mean doing it twice for the two file versions.

Guiguts will insert Hebrew properly, but will display it backward (LTR instead of RTL).

Visual Studio Code will both insert and display properly.

Atom doesn't work for this - don't use it.
cards.name: Hebrew

cards.desc: Set up guiguts so it is aware of the book's page numbering. This makes it easy to locate things later, especially after page markers have been removed, and the page numbers also get used in the HTML version.
cards.name: Page number fixup

cards.desc:
Make a list of illustrations that need to be handled. They are located in `pngs/`, named e.g. `cover`,`i001`,` illus-001`...

Move these images to the `illustrations/` folder.

It may help to open two windows to compare the illustrations to verify which ones go in which locations. This assumes the high-quality scans are JPEG files instead of PNG files. They were in `winefred`.

```
cd pngs
open -a Preview *.png ## did this earlier?
open -a Preview *.jpg
```
cards.name: Catalog illustrations

cards.desc:
Blank pages are meaningless in the electronic version, so we remove them.

**Remember to check the page is really blank!**
cards.name: Remove blank pages

cards.desc: Look for orphaned markup (unmatched brackets / tags). NOTE: it's probably worth looking for these at the beginning. We will render our HTML, so it's not that likely we'll have bad output there. But the proofers and foofers may have left unbalanced tags in the text. If punctuation is part of an entire italicized sentence, the punctuation should be inside the tag. Otherwise, if it's only a word or a phrase (not the entire sentence) then the punctuation does not belong inside the italics. ``` Search: ()([!?;:]) Replace: $2$1 ```
cards.name: Orphaned DP markup

cards.desc:
Check each proofer's note and handle as appropriate.

Search for `[*` (no regex!) to find them. Make notes in `README.md` as needed, and also in Transcriber's Notes as needed.
cards.name: Proofer's notes

cards.desc:
The purpose of this skim is to page through the book looking for all the stuff that's not "just text," and make sure it's looked at. This will hopefully be gone through again as we go, but it's a good idea to hit on the obvious things right at the start too.

**Remember, taking a note is also an action.** Not everything has to be fixed in this pass, just noticed.
cards.name: First-pass skim

cards.desc:
Find hyphenated words and handle appropriately.

Search for `-*` (no regex!). Take notes and update TN as necessary.
cards.name: Hyphenated words in question

cards.desc:
If book uses Mr., Mrs., and so on, might want to check for those with a space after (e.g. search for missing periods).

```
Search: (Dr|M(me|lle|essrs|rs?)|St)\s
```
cards.name: Abbreviated titles missing periods

cards.desc:
If your book uses small-caps A.D., B.C., A.M., P.M., and so on, fix for HTML.

```
Search: [A-Z]\.\s*[A-Z]\.
```
cards.name: <sc> A.D., B.C., et al.

cards.desc:
This is a swiss army knife tool, looks for a lot of different stuff.

In each section, `Search` until there's no more matches, then `Next Stealtho` to go to the next thing in the list. Each `.rc` file has multiple things it looks for.
cards.name: Stealth Scannos

cards.desc:
Look at various odd cases.

When looking in `Hyphens`, note that for Google Ngram, you must put spaces around the hyphen in a hyphenated word, `foo - bar` not `foo-bar`. Otherwise it is interpreted as `foo but not bar`.
cards.name: Word Frequency

cards.desc: Bookloupe is just a guide, it is not always right.
cards.name: Bookloupe

cards.desc:
Careful spell check. Use the old dictionaries and Ngrams if needed.

Try to do this before a bunch of ppgen markup has been added!
cards.name: Spellcheck

cards.desc:
Txt → Convert to Curly Quotes

There are two other Curly Quote tools just under that menu item; look into those as well.
cards.name: Curly quotes

cards.desc:
Superscripts are denoted with `^`, examples:

```
M^cCaskill
The 9^{th} regiment
```

It is up to PP to determine how to handle these. For instance you can simply turn `9^{th}` into `9th` or you can leave it that way and add a TN describing what you've done.

Just be consistent so that the reader knows what it means.
cards.name: Superscripts

cards.desc:
Convert the thought breaks.

Search for `<tb>` and replace with `.tb`

Don’t use the Guiguts tool, it doesn’t know about ppgen syntax.
cards.name: Thought breaks

cards.desc:
Change ligatures to UTF8.

```
Search: \[(oe|OE|ae|AE)\]
Replacements: æ Æ œ Œ
```

Also look for `[]`brackets (without `*`) to find things like macrons.

```
Search: \[[^*]
```
cards.name: Ligature, etc fixup

cards.desc:
Replace `--` with UTF-8 em-dash.

```
[^-]--[^-]
```

When ppgen generates its output files, it will use "—" for the em-dashes in the utf8.txt file and the .html file. For the lat1.txt file ppgen will convert the em-dashes back to "--".

Single dashes are in 2 categories:

- A hyphen, which should be left as-is
- An en-dash, which can be inserted as the UTF-8 character.

An en-dash is appropriate in these cases:

- Range of numbers `12–15`
- A mathematical minus sign `15 – 12 = 3`
- Negative numbers `–14º`

[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/En-dash](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/En-dash "‌")
cards.name: Dashes

cards.desc:
Set up source file so it is aware of the book's page numbering. This makes it easy to locate things later.

```
Search: ^-+File: (\d+\.png)-+\s*$
Replace: .bn $1\n.pn +1
```

‌

- ppgen has facilities for page numbering but, also png numbering
- Insert a comment to replace a page marker
- Set the page number with e.g. `.pn 1`
- Advance page number by 1 with `.pn +1`
- Set a .bin file up for this page with e.g. `.bn 001.png`

See also [Page Numbering](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Manual#Page_Numbering "‌").
cards.name: Page numbering for ppgen

cards.desc: The front matter (title page, copyright, TOC, and other stuff that comes before the main body of the book) are full of unusual items that require close scrutiny to handle correctly.
cards.name: Front matter

cards.desc:
Make it look nice. Probably most of it should be centered?

- .h1 for main heading. use once.
- .h2 for chapters
- .h3 for sections
- .h4, .h5, and .h6 for lower-level headings

.h1 and .h2 can have title= attribute.

.h1 - .h6 can have break/nobreak, id=, pn=, align=[lcr]

For .h1 - .h3 default is break. For .h4 - .h6 default is nobreak.
cards.name: Format title page

cards.desc:
Remember you use `.pb` for page break and you can use sizing tags for text size and `|` for a new line.

```
.h1 for main heading. use once.
.h2 for chapters
.h3 for sections
.h4, .h5, and .h6 for lower-level headings
```

For example:

```
.sp 4
.h2 id=ch01
<l>THE GENTLEMAN FROM SAN</l>|<l>FRANCISCO</l>
```

Chapters don't seem to need `.pb` before... need to experiment with that.
cards.name: Chapters (h2), Sections (h3)

cards.desc:
If each item has trailing comma, don't remove it.

If the original didn't have a Table of Contents, mention in the TN that this has been added by the transcriber.
cards.name: Table of Contents

cards.desc: Each italic tag is categorized semantically. Search: `((.|\n)+?)` Replace (multiple): - `$1` - `$1` - `$1` Categories: - ` ` is used when a word is italic for emphasis in the text. - ` ` is used when a reference is cited. The New York Times, Washington Irving, etc. - ` ` is used to indicate a language other than the original's in the text. ("Bonjour, m'ami!" he shouted.) -- Note that the "lang" tag does not italicize, so you want to include the italic tag here. - If none of these fit, just leave as ` ` [HTML lang codes](http://www.w3schools.com/tags/ref_language_codes.asp "‌")
cards.name: Italic semantic fixup

cards.desc:
If this book uses drop caps, add those.

Use `.dc` for text (`.di` is for drop cap images).

If a book has the drop cap text printed all in one case, but it contains a capital letter such as a name, _preserve the capital_ even though it will look different. Some epub formatters, including ADE, cannot do small caps, so then you will end up with an improper case.

**On sizing of dropcaps:**

You can control the sizing of text dropcaps with the `dcs` register.

_dcs -- The dcs register controls the font size used for drop caps (.dc command). The default value is 250%._
 _Example: This will set the drop cap font size to 420% of the base font size:_  `.nr dcs 420%`

[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Manual#Named_Registers](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Manual#Named_Registers "smartCard-inline")

**For illustrated drop caps, leave this for when images are processed.**

[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Manual#Drop\_Caps\_.28Letters.29](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Manual#Drop_Caps_.28Letters.29 "‌")
cards.name: Drop caps

cards.desc:
If this book uses drop caps, add those.

Use `.dc` for text (`.di` is for drop cap images).

If a book has the drop cap text printed all in one case, but it contains a capital letter such as a name, _preserve the capital_ even though it will look different. Some epub formatters, including ADE, cannot do small caps, so then you will end up with an improper case.

**For illustrated drop caps, leave this for when images are processed.**

[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Manual#Drop\_Caps\_.28Letters.29](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Manual#Drop_Caps_.28Letters.29 "‌")
cards.name: Drop caps

cards.desc:
There is a good [case study](http://www.pgdp.org/~jana/best-practices/pages/case-studies/poetry/) on this topic, but here are the highlights.

A poem is made up of stanzas. A stanza is made up of lines. A line may be indented.

Normally stanzas are separated by a blank line. A poem may consist of only one stanza.

Basic formatting:

```
.nf b
line 1
line 2
...
.nb-
```

**TODO:** how to format if not all lines are the same indent?

Centering has usually resulted In the ebook version not being centered, instead it will be indented by `1.5em`. This is because many ebook readers don't grok the centering method, and are usually on smaller screens anyway.
cards.name: Formatting poetry / songs

cards.desc:
Look for `/* */` and `/# #/` blocks to process.

`/#` indicates differently-printed but wrappable text, e.g. blockquotes.

Example for an indented blockquote:

```
.in +4
.ll -4
<text...>
.in
.ll
```

`/*` indicates non-wrappable text that needs special formatting.
cards.name: Check for wrapping markers

cards.desc:
[Footnote handling in PPgen](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Tutorial/Footnotes "‌")

TODO: look at footnote fixup tool

TL;DR:

- The footnote mark is like this: `[1]` or `[A]`
- Use `.fn` for each footnote.
- Use `.fm lz=<type>` to designate where to drop footnotes.

The `<type>` is one of:

- `.fm lz=t` - put them here in text version
- `.fm lz=h` - put them here in HTML version
- `.fm lz=th` - put them here in both text & HTML versions
cards.name: Footnotes

cards.desc:
[Miller's workflow](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/User:Miller#Text_Version_Footnotes)

Must be done before rewrapping the text.
cards.name: Footnotes [Guiguts tile]

cards.desc:
From lhamilton’s list, stuff to look into:

# First Pass

"Fixup" -> "Footnote Fixup" - "First Pass" button. Guiguts moves thru identifying anything it thinks is a Footnote and its associated anchor. The pass will finish with the first footnote anchor highlighted in orange, the actual associated footnote in green. At the top of the Footnote pop-up, it shows how many footnotes are in the text. It may help you to select "Unlimited Anchor Search" if your footnote markers are a long way away from the actual footnote text.

# Check Footnotes

Hit the "Check Footnotes" button. Pop-up lists all footnotes found. Footnotes marked in yellow have duplicate anchors, footnotes marked in pink have no anchors. Use the "Go to - #" footnote dropdown in the Footnote tool to fix any errors. & re-run First Pass & Check Footnotes to make sure all errors have been fixed.

# Check Footnote Count

"Fixup" -> "Run Word Frequency Routine" -> "Sort Alpha" -> "Re Run". Look for how many times the word "Footnote" occurs in the text, it should match the number of Footnotes found by the Footnote tool, if it doesn't you have a missing Footnote somewhere, use the features of Word Frequency lists mentioned in 2.6.3 to fix any errors. Run the Footnote "First Pass" step if you fix any errors.

# Step through all Footnotes

"Next FN -->" & "<-- Last FN" buttons to step your way through the Footnotes guiguts has found, fixing any errors and joining any multi-page footnotes. You can use the "See Anchor" & "See Footnote" buttons to make sure that the anchor is associated with the correct footnote text. If you fix a missing ending bracket problem, hit the "Adjust Bounds" button and guiguts will find the new closing bracket. For each footnote, select the appropriate symbol style to use with the "Number", "Letter" or "Roman" buttons. You can use the "IMAGE" button to check the original symbol style if needed. Numbers are recommended if you have large numbers of footnotes. Don't worry about removing duplicate footnote symbols, this will be handled auto-magically in the next step. Guiguts depends on Footnotes being in the right format, [?] for markers and [Footnote ?: text] for the footnote. Make sure you correct all footnotes to this format. You can set manual anchors if you have lots of footnotes in [Footnote: ? text] format, see the guiguts manual on how to handle those.

# Index Footnotes

Once you have stepped through and checked, adjusted, fixed and anchored all of your footnotes, hit the "Re Index" button. For out-of-line footnotes, this will renumber all of the footnotes using the same family of symbol that it had originally or a number if it had no anchor marker. This will close up any gaps in the numbers and remove duplicates. You can make changes and re index as often as you like.
cards.name: Footnotes: review items

cards.desc:
Illustrations are in `illustrations/` to clean up `pngs/`, but save the final output images to `images` folder.

(In June 2020, the guidelines were updated by PG, see [this thread](https://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=70286 "‌")).

Add alt tags on images, PPgen’s text output will include them as an illustration description.

## Covers

Covers should be at least 650x1000 pixels (width x height) and up to 5000x5000 pixels. Larger dimensions are recommended. Cover file size should be no larger than 256K.

## Inline images

Normal illustrations should be no larger than 256K and up to 5000x5000 pixels in dimension.

## Linked-to images

Images that are targets of an href can be no larger than 1 MB and up to 5000x5000 pixels.

They should be sized proportional to how much space they took on the printed page. e.g. an illustrated drop cap is probably only 100-125px tall. Using the image guidelines as a guide, you can also control the rendering size using CSS width. But an image should only be as large as needed, we still don't want to balloon download sizes unnecessarily.

## File format

Monochrome images, use PNG. Color images use JPEG.

JPEG can't do transparency, if you need transparency, add an alpha channel to the source image and export as PNG.

JPEG is much more compressible, so a large PNG can probably benefit from being converted to JPEG.

Images with captions don't need an `alt` tag, but if you use one it will be included as a note in PPgen’s text output.

[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Guide_to_Image_Processing](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Guide_to_Image_Processing "smartCard-inline")

[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/DP_Official_Documentation:PP_and_PPV/Post-Processing_FAQ#Preparing_illustrations_for_the_HTML_version](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/DP_Official_Documentation:PP_and_PPV/Post-Processing_FAQ#Preparing_illustrations_for_the_HTML_version "smartCard-inline")

If fixing the image is beyond your ability, try asking for help in the [Illustrators thread](http://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=17712 "‌").

cards.desc: If the book has a list of illustrations, treat it like a TOC. Copy that card and process it the same way, except for the checklist items here.

cards.desc:
Use `.di` for drop-cap images.

[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Manual#Drop_Caps_.28Images.29](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PPTools/Ppgen/Manual#Drop_Caps_.28Images.29 "smartCard-inline")

If the drop-cap doesn’t flow right, you can try to use a div to force a clear…

```
.de .brk {width:100%;clear:both;}

// fix flow around drop caps
.dv class="brk"
\&
.dv-
```

cards.desc:
If you modify an image substantially, e.g. removing a library sticker or stamp, add a mention of this in the TN (front matter). Also indicate the new image is placed in the public domain, as discused [here](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Easy_Epub/Cover).

This is a PG requirement. The link includes HTML/CSS for adding a front matter TN, if needed.
cards.name: Substantially changing an image

cards.desc: [https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages "smartCard-inline") If no cover was provided, you should fabricate one for the ebook. See [here](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Easy_Epub/Cover "‌") for more information. And [here](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages/Blank_Book_Covers "‌") are blank cover images to start from. You will need a front matter TN, and a public domain declaration. This is a PG requirement. Something like "The cover image was created by the transcriber and is placed in the public domain." See below for code. In ppgen, wrap this disclaimer with an HTML test. There is no cover in the text file, therefore no reason for the disclaimer. ``` .if h .de div.tnotes { padding-left:1em;padding-right:1em;background-color:#E3E4FA;border:1px solid silver; margin:2em 10% 0 10%; } .de .covernote { visibility: hidden; display: none; } .de div.tnotes p { text-align:left; } .de @media handheld { .covernote { visibility: visible; display: block;} } .dv class="tnotes covernote" Transcriber's Note: New original cover art included with this eBook is granted to the public domain. .dv- .if- ``` The HTML version doesn't really need a cover, so if we are at the point of fabricating one, then we only want it to be applied to the ebook. The above ppgen code will result in an HTML file that won't display the cover. The ebook will still include the cover. DP policy is that when fabricating a cover image, we use only images found within the book as provided (not images found in other versions of the book, or images from anywhere else). See more at the above link. There is a [team thread](http://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=57674 "‌") of people who are willing to volunteer to create custom covers for projects. ## Pixelmator Pro how-to First grab a [generic cover image](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages/Blank_Book_Covers "‌"), at least 1600x2560 pixels. Select a font. All-caps and something akin to the title page font might be a good selection. Serif fonts are probably best. Here are some possibilities: - Academy Engraved LET - Palatino - Times New Roman Use as large a font size as will fit: 96 point generally works, or 72 if necessary; and perhaps much smaller for "By" above an Author's name. Center it. Try to use a color complementary to the cover's color. Add the title and author text on separate layers. That way they can be moved around.
cards.name: Fabricating a cover

cards.desc:
First grab a [generic cover image](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages/Blank_Book_Covers), at least 1600x2560 pixels.

Select a font. All-caps and something akin to the title page font might be a good selection. Serif fonts are probably best. Here are some possibilities:

* Academy Engraved LET
* Palatino
* Times New Roman

Use as large a font size as will fit: 96 point generally works, or 72 if necessary; and perhaps much smaller for "By" above an Author's name. Center it. Try to use a color complementary to the cover's color.

Add the title and author text on separate layers. That way they can be moved around.
cards.name: Fabricating a cover: Pixelmator Pro

cards.desc:
[https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages "smartCard-inline")

If no cover was provided, you should fabricate one for the ebook. See [here](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Easy_Epub/Cover "‌") for more information.

And [here](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages/Blank_Book_Covers "‌") are blank cover images to start from.

You will need a public domain declaration. This is a PG requirement. This should go into the Transcriber’s Notes at the end of the book.

> New original cover art included with this eBook is granted to the public domain.

In ppgen, wrap this disclaimer with an HTML test. There is no cover in the text file, therefore no reason for the disclaimer.

```
.if h
.de .covernote { visibility: hidden; display: none; }
.de .x-ebookmaker .covernote { visibility: visible; display: block; }
.dv class="covernote"
New original cover art included with this eBook is granted to the public domain.
.dv-
.if-
```

The HTML version doesn't really need a cover, so if we are at the point of fabricating one, then we only want it to be applied to the ebook. The above ppgen code will result in an HTML file that won't display the cover. The ebook will still include the cover.

DP policy is that when fabricating a cover image, we use only images found within the book as provided (not images found in other versions of the book, or images from anywhere else). See more at the above link.

There is a [team thread](http://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=57674 "‌") of people who are willing to volunteer to create custom covers for projects.

## Pixelmator Pro how-to

First grab a [generic cover image](https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/PP_guide_to_cover_pages/Blank_Book_Covers "‌"), at least 1600x2560 pixels.

Select a font. All-caps and something akin to the title page font might be a good selection. Serif fonts are probably best. Here are some possibilities:

- Academy Engraved LET
- Palatino
- Times New Roman

Use as large a font size as will fit: 96 point generally works, or 72 if necessary; and perhaps much smaller for "By" above an Author's name. Center it. Try to use a color complementary to the cover's color.

Add the title and author text on separate layers. That way they can be moved around.

cards.desc: If fixing the image is beyond your ability, try asking for help in the [Illustrators thread](http://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=17712).
cards.name: Outsourcing image modifications

cards.desc:
Transparent PNG works fine for iBooks and ADE apps. Kindle seems to ignore transparency and uses the background color (or defaults to black if there isn't any background color data present).

If using Gimp, export as PNG, using these options:

- [_] Interlacing (Adam7)
- [X] Save background color
- [_] Save gamma
- [_] Save layer offset
- [X] Save resolution
- [X] Save creation time
- [_] Save comment
- [_] Save color values from transparent pixels

In my testing, this still renders non-transparent in Kindle app (it is on a white background if you switch to another background color), but it's better than before when I had a black blackground on the default white page. Renders transparent/correct in iBooks & ADE.
cards.name: Transparent PNGs

cards.desc: Add the transcriber's notes that you've been keeping. I use the original book's page numbers for some reason, it's better than using the image numbers I guess, even though in the text version there are no page numbers. **Leading TN, if any, should be right after** `.dt` **before the Page 1 mark** Include a bit of text for change entries, so the reader can find the place you changed. `p. 123: changed "foo" to "fool" (the fool and his money)` An easy boilerplate to start from: ``` .h2 Transcriber’s Notes Some inconsistencies in spelling, hyphenation, and punctuation have been retained. .if t This file uses underscores to indicate italic text. .if- ```
cards.name: Add TN

cards.desc: Add the transcriber's notes that you've been keeping. I use the original book's page numbers; it's better than using the image numbers, even though in the output text version there are no page numbers. Include a bit of text for change entries, so the reader can find the place you changed. `p. 123: changed "foo" to "fool" (the fool and his money)` A boilerplate to start from: ``` .pb .de .tnotes { width: 80%; margin: auto; padding: 0 1em; background-color: #E3E4FA; border: 1px solid silver; } .dv class="tnotes" .ce Transcriber’s Notes: Some inconsistencies in spelling, hyphenation, and punctuation have been retained. .if t This file uses underscores to indicate italic text. .if- .dv- ```
cards.name: Add TN

```
\n\n\n
```

cards.desc: `make ppgen`

cards.desc: https://www.pgdp.net/ppwb/index.php
cards.name: PP workbench checks
PPTools

cards.desc:
1. Don't use `!important` in CSS, this seems to break ADE. It seems it can't parse the CSS, so all CSS is ignored.

2. ADE does not recognize smallcaps.

3. Kindle (at least for Mac) seems to render transparent PNG backgrounds as black.

4. Apple Books sometimes adds extra blank pages where you don't want or expect them. I don't know why.

5. Kindle (at least on Mac) does not seem to honor `page-break-*` CSS. EPUB seems to, or at least iBooks and ADE on Mac do.

6. If you build ebooks and do not have a cover yet, the first illustration is assumed to be the cover. This may render things like illustrations or title page publisher stamps invisible.
cards.name: Ebook notes

cards.desc:
https://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=15019&p=1102349#p1102349

> Kindle screwup; it does not respect attribute: `width` on a div. But setting all of `min-width`, `width`, and `max-width` explicitly fixes the problem. I suspect that Kindle probably sets `min-width` to `100%`, and my setting it over-rides the kindle spec.

---

> Kindle ignores `max-width`, as Richard said.
>
> If you want your narrow text to be centered (column-centered with smooth margins), add `margin: auto;` to the "narrow" definition. Otherwise, it'll be left-positioned along the body's main left margin.
cards.name: Kindle and narrow columns

cards.desc:
To side-load via USB, add the file to `Documents/`, **not** `Books/`.
It will show up in the Docs section on the device, not under Books.

When ejecting, first eject the device on Mac, and then tap "Disconnect" on the device, and then pull the USB cable.
cards.name: Kindle Fire notes

cards.desc: Build `.epub`and `.epub3` books and review.
cards.name: Review ebooks

cards.desc: The TOC generated by the ebook makers should have proper book structure. If not, then something is wrong. There should only be one `<h1>` used, and `<h2>` should only be used for things that should be in the TOC. If there are things that don't belong there, reformat using non-header tags.
cards.name: Review ebook TOC

cards.desc:
Once fairly confident you are done, submit to SR for 4+ weeks (maybe longer for a long title).

People say it's hard to get anybody to SR their books. But these books have been sitting around for a century, a few more weeks won’t matter.
cards.name: Submit to Smooth Reading

cards.desc:
SR will hopefully have feedback for you. As it comes in, process it.

Send feedback to the SR. If you choose to ignore something they brought up, explain why you made that decision.
cards.name: Process SR feedback

cards.desc: If SR had any feedback, run through the "Finish and validate" list checks again before PPV, just in case.

cards.name: Guide to DU and Posting to PG

cards.desc:
DU now requires a link to ebookmaker’s output.txt. Run the book through online ebookmaker, and check the output.txt. There should not be any errors (warnings are OK).

Get a link to the output.txt file; it will be needed for the upload form.

**The online ebooks & output.txt only persist ~3 days.**
cards.name: Online ebookmaker (for output.txt)

```
make zip
```

Produces file: `zipdir/$(PROJECT).zip`
cards.name: Create upload zip file

cards.desc:
[Upload site](https://upload.pglaf.org/)

The copyright clearance key should be on the project page.
cards.name: Upload form: initial steps

cards.desc:
Check the title page scan and confirm submission details as supplied at clearance time. **CHECK CAREFULLY**, making any needed changes. See checklist below.

If you need to make additional changes (that don't fit the items below) but are unable to do so, please mention this in the **Notes** field. For example, you may wish to add a Translator, but have already used up all the available spaces on the form. Please enter this information in the Notes field.

### On title capitalization

If English, title should be capitalized using Sentence caps.

Example: The story of the little red hen

Proper nouns such as names should be capitalized.

Some examples from recent [gutenberg.org](http://gutenberg.org "‌") titles:

- What the wind did
- The writing of fiction
- Travels in Africa, Egypt, and Syria from the year 1792 to 1798
- The Squire's young folk : A Christmas story

For titles in languages other than English (LOTE), please follow the capitalization used on the book's Title Page. However, if the title there is fully capitalized, please use the conventions for title capitalization common in the book's language (If in doubt, you may refer to the capitalization used for books in that language within the catalogs of major libraries such as the Library of Congress or WorldCat).
cards.name: Upload form: verify title page / metadata

cards.desc:
The credits line appears in the DP project comments and should be copied and pasted into the credit line from the project page. You may need to edit the credits line by deleting duplicate names, moving image provider credit to the end, etc.

Assume that the words "Produced by" will be prefixed to whatever you enter. Otherwise, be sure to enter the credits line EXACTLY as it should appear in the posted file, and as it appears on the project page (check the project page when you're uploading). The Whitewashers will not edit this information; it will be copied directly into the posted file.

Please be sure all names are spelled correctly, and contain no unicode characters; verify that all names of volunteers or institutions that need to be mentioned are included.

Example of a credit line to be entered in this field:

> `Joe Schmo, Jane Doe, and the Online Distributed Proofreading Team at https://www.pgdp.net (This file was produced from images generously made available by The Internet Archive/American Libraries.)`
cards.name: Upload form: Credits line

cards.desc:
Please use this field to communicate with the Whitewashers. You may wish to indicate that this is your first upload, or you may wish to draw their attention to a particular issue, or you may leave this field blank.

If there are drop-caps, note this for WW. Per this PPgen warning.

```
**warning: CSS3 drop-cap. Please note in upload.
```
cards.name: Upload form: Notes (if needed)

cards.desc:
Always use Preview first. It will let you know if you have any extra files in your zip file, if the HTML does not validate, or if there is some other problem with your file.

If all is well, in preview mode you will see something like the following:

> user's upload was UTF-8testing turkeyinthestraw.html HTML Tidy: No warnings or errors were found. W3C HTML check passed CSS passed (level 3) Valid links and anchors

If there is a problem, you may see a message warning of invalid HTML, CSS or bad links, etc.

Details of the problems will be provided via a link to a temporary location on PG's server. If the preview indicates any problems with the HTML, please revise to address these problems, and upload the file for preview again.

**Only submit if the preview no longer indicates any problems.**
cards.name: Preview first! then submit

cards.desc: **Only submit if the preview no longer indicates any problems.**
cards.name: Submit

cards.desc:
After submitting your file, you will receive an email confirming your submission.[*] The PG Whitewashers will check your file, post it to the PG archive, and send you an email notifying you that it has been posted. After the file has posted, the project will be removed from your PP queue by one of the site admins.

If your file has not been posted **within one week**, please contact the Whitewashers at pgww@lists.pglaf.org. Occasionally uploads fail; for this reason, please always keep a copy of your uploaded files until you receive a posting note.

[*] There's sometimes a problem with the confirming email. If you don't receive a confirmation, just wait and see what happens.

**Never** re-upload a project, except if expressly requested to do so by a WWer.
cards.name: Wait for posting...

cards.desc:
If you notice an error after you have uploaded your file, email pgww@lists.pglaf.org as soon as possible to alert the Whitewashers.

If you notice an error in one of your recently posted files, email details to the Whitewasher who posted it, or email pgww@lists.pglaf.org.

If you notice an error in an older PG file (posted more than one month previously), you may report the error to errata@pglaf.org.

If at any time you have questions about uploading, you may contact the Whitewashers (pgww@lists.pglaf.org).

DP has a forum (PG Direct Uploading/PPVing) where you may ask questions or search for answers to your queries.

If you've got any other question or problem, please contact the PPV co-coordinator (ppv-coord@pgdp.net).
cards.name: Contacts

cards.desc: Update various points in the project with the final ebook link.
cards.name: Update project with links

cards.desc:
Now that the book is published, we probably don't need the space-consuming Pixelmator/Gimp formatted files anymore, especially if this project had a lot of illustrations.

Similarly, we don't need the ebooks or the zip archive; we can always regenerate those from the sources if we want to.

Tools -> Word Frequency
Set to `Alph`, click `Rerun`
`Emdashes` to validate em-dashes
`Hyphens` to look for words both hyphenated and not. Also look for odd words that look like hyphen simply doesn't belong there like `in-the`
`Alpha/num` to look for numbers hiding in words like `lone1y`
`Ital/Bold/SC` to look for punctuation in tags that should be moved outside
`MiXeD CasE` to look for `MacArthur` vs `Macarthur`
`Character Cnts`, there should be same number of `[` as `]` for instance
`Check , Upper` looks for comma followed by uppercase
`Check . lower` looks for period followed by lowercase
`Check Accents` looks for accented words and similar words `resumé, resume`.
Tools -> Stealth Scannos -> regex. Check `Auto Advance`.
Click `Search`. If nothing happened, do it again.
`Next Stealtho` when done with this stealtho
Swap the terms and do it again (if there are multiple terms like en-commn)
Repeat process for `en-commn`. Check `Whole Word`.
Tools -> Spell Query
Tools -> Bookloupe
Click `View Options`
Check `Long line`
Check `Short line`
Close window
Scroll past `\d queries` line
Right-click line to mark it OK, click to go see it in text.
Check `No CR`
Reassemble footnotes that are split into multiple pieces
Place all footnotes between paragraphs
`Tools -> Footnote Fixup`
Click `First Pass` to parse / tally up footnotes
Click `Check Footnotes` and address problems. Want all white (brown is OK if they're just long footnotes).
Determine if they can all just be renumbered globally. Check `All to Number` or `All to Letter`...
Click `Reindex`
Click `Autoset Chapter LZ`, then `Move FNs to Landing Zone(s)`
Click `Tidy Up Footnotes`
Footnotes for the last chapter may end up below the TN. Move those.
Search for `FOOTNOTES:`, change to `FOOTNOTE:` if there's only one.
Enter copyright clearance key
Choose zip file
Add dp-post@pgdp.net as a Cc on the Posted announcement
Author field contains data
Author's name is spelled correctly
All authors listed on title page are listed in upload form
Any illustrator, translator, editor, etc., listed on title page is listed in upload form
Title is complete and all words are spelled correctly
Title is appropriately capitalized (see above notes on this)
Subtitle listed on title page is listed in upload form
If you are uploading a periodical, please check Project Gutenberg for previously posted issues of that periodical and follow the title formatting they used.
If your project is part of a multiple volume set, state the number, i.e. English History, (Vol. 2/6).
Search -> Find Orphaned DP Markup
Do italic search noted above
Search for `<i>` and check for general punctuation to move inside.
Right-click on `Lbl: None` button in guiguts
Click `See image` button
Go to first page's image
If any roman numbering, use Roman instead of Arabic for those
Find first Arabic numbered page, set that to Arabic, change `+1` to `Start @` and enter page number, e.g. `1`.
Press `Recalculate` button to renumber the pages
Go to last page of book, make sure it matches the numbering you expected. If it doesn't, it might be blank pages or illustration-only pages, which often do not get page numbers (more on those later)
